column2: the sole companion of King Thrór when he set out to wander in the wilds of Middle-earth.

column1: Virtually nothing is known of Nár. However what is known is that he set out with the King of Durin’s folk from Dunland
column2: where the Thrórs following of relatives and subjects were living at the time to find his fortunes in wider world.

column1: Their journey eventually brought them to the old Dwarves-halls of Moria
column2: now infested with Orcs and Trolls. Disregarding the pleas of Nár
column3: Thrór insisted on entering Moria while Nár stayed behind and waited for the king not far from the gate.

column1: That was the last any Dwarf ever saw of Thrór alive. He was beheaded by the Orcs
column2: and their chieftain Azog branded his own name on Thrórs brow. The Orcs allowed Nár to live so he could return to Thrórs son Thráin
column3: with a message that Azog now ruled in Moria
column4: and that Dwarves best stay away lest they suffer the same fate.

column1: Nár returned to Dunland where his message caused such anger amongst his people that it raised a call to arms among all seven Dwarf Houses to avenge the elder high-king of their race
column2: leading the War of the Dwarves and Orcs.

column1: In the climactic Battle of Azanulbizar
column2: Azog himself was slain along with thousands of others on both sides.

column1: Nár is a dwarf from the Völuspá. His name means "Corpse".Chester Nathan Gould
column2: "Dwarf-Names: A Study in Old Icelandic Religion"
column3: published in Publications of the Modern Language Association of America
